results.title: 5 Minutes with Wlad
results.creator_credit: Alison Wotherspoon, Flinders University and Roger David
results.brief_description: The purpose of this documentary is to draw attention to the fact that sometimes, people are not what they seem to be. Far too often we tend to pass judgement on face value and often if we dig a little deeper, we will be very surprised at our findings. At first glance Wlad’s appearance pertains to all the stereotypical constructs of a vagabond or street drunk. As the camera moves in for a closer look the extraordinary world of Wlad the artist is revealed to us. The man was a POW in Poland and was forced to paint propaganda portraits of Stalin in order to save his own life while members of his family were carted off to concentration camps and killed.

results.title: 5 for 4
results.brief_description: Wartime Savings campaign publicity created by film artist Norman McLaren. Symbolic figures, drawn directly on film stock move and dance against a simple painted background. The music is from a recording of “Pinetop Boogie”, played by Albert Ammons. The technique of Vitacolour was used, a three-colour process now obsolete.

results.title: 5 Films about Christo & Jeanne-Claude
results.creator_credit: Grahame Weinbren, Susan Froemke, Deborah Dickson, Charlotte Zwerin, Ellen Hovde, David Maysles, Albert Maysles and Maysles Films, Inc.
results.brief_description: Since the early 1960s Christo and Jean-Claude’s large-scale temporary works of art have worked to change our perceptions of the relationship between art and society - so writes famed documentary filmmaker Albert Maysles, a close friend of the Christos’ who has, over the decades, studied their numerous struggles to see their art realised. In these five documentaries Christo and his wife’s work habits are laid bare including their ambitions and conflicts with bureaucrats which constitute a significant portion of their work. Works include: “Christos Valley Curtain” Academy Award nominated film that celebrates the hanging of a huge orange curtain between two Colorado mountains. “Running Fence” An engrossing document of the efforts to build a 24 and 1/2 mile long, 18 foot high fence of white fabric across the hills of Northern California. “Islands” Christo and Jean-Claude fight to surround eleven islands in Miami’s Biscayne Bay with 6.5 million square feet of bright pink fabric. “Christo in Paris” The wrapping of the Pont Neuf in Paris and a portrait of the artists lasting love affair. “Umbrellas” Thousands of umbrellas are simultaneously opened in rice-farming valley in Japan and across a cluster of cattle ranches in southern California. This is great collection about an iconic artist at work that is accompanied by fascinating commentaries, a glossy booklet and an extensive interview with the artists.

results.title: 5 colours of France = Five colours of France
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: 1. An open zoo 25 miles east of Paris. 2. Sculpture exhibition at la Place des Vosges. 3. The festival of theatre arts in the Marais district of Paris. 4. “Commissioner San Antonio” - a new thriller being filmed.

results.title: 5 colours of France = 5 couleurs de France
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items including: 1. Bouquinistes on the River Seine. 2. Castillo - showing of his 1967-68 fashion designs. 3. Exhibition of “old time” posters from 1900 - art by Toulous le Trec is a part of this collection. 4. Behind the scenes look at Jean Luc Godard at work on his new film “Weekend”. 5. “Phoenetic Art” is on exhibition with the theme of “Light and Movement” at the Paris Museum of Modern Art.

results.title: 49th Parallel
results.creator_credit: General Film Distributions, Ortus and Michael Powell
results.brief_description: After the sinking of Nazi U-boat 37 by the Royal Canadian Air Force during World War II, six Nazi survivors of the attack reach an Eskimo village and commit every sort of crime in their effort to reach the neutral territory of the U.S. This is an important and effective example of propaganda films. Cast includes Laurence Olivier, Leslie Howard, Raymond Massey and Glynis Johns.

results.title: 48 hrs = 48 hours [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Lawrence Gordon, Joel Silver and Walter Hill
results.brief_description: 48 Hrs set the blueprint for the successful comedy/action/buddy genre film in Hollywood. Jack Cates (Nick Nolte) is a white renegade cop determined to avenge the murder of several colleagues at the hands of criminals. The only way to find the killers is to allow one of their crew, a street-wise hustler out of jail. Reggie Hammond (Eddie Murphy) is given forty-eight hours leave from jail to assist with the investigation. Hammond and Cates hate one another on sight, but have to learn to work together, perhaps even like each other to crack the case. Murphy was still a member of the television show “Saturday Night Live” when he made his debut film, which broke him in the mainstream. His profane shtick became his signature routine, which would see him through many phases of his bountiful career. The film consists of numerous violent set-ups and shoot-outs as well as exciting action sequences.

results.title: 42nd Street
results.creator_credit: Hal B Wallis, Warner Bros Pictures, Vitaphone and Lloyd Bacon
results.brief_description: Here’s your ticket to “Shuffle off to Buffalo” with Ruby Keeler and Dick Powell in this beguiling Busby Berkeley showcase; a bold, enticing feast of choreography and imagination. Warner Baxter stars as Julian Marsh, a tyrannical director of Broadway musicals. When his show’s leading lady, played by Bebe Daniels, breaks her ankle on the eve of opening night, a wide-eyed chorus girl played by Ruby Keeler is thrust into the role. Also stars George Brent, Una Merkel and Dick Powell.

results.title: 42 Up
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “World in action”.
In 1964 a team from Granada Television set out to test the following theory - are children’s lives already mapped out for them by the age of seven? This was the start of a remarkable series which documents groups of children from childhood through puberty to adulthood. Of the original 14 subjects, 11 remain. Now halfway through their lives, how close are they to realising their dreams and ambitions? This enthralling film also starts asking grander questions common to all humans - what is love, what is character, what is success?
